item.title: A French Fair as Workers’ Paradise, Feting Cuisine, Music and Communism
item.description: The Fête de l’Humanité, a blend of Burning Man, Woodstock and a political convention, attracts the masses with bands, lectures and food, but here K.F.C. is C.F.K.: Communist Fried Kitchen.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fête de l’Humanité, a popular festival on the outskirts of Paris, celebrates left-wing politics in general, and French Communism in particular.

item.title: Live Updates: Netanyahu and Hezbollah Trade Fresh Threats
item.description: The Israeli leader vowed to take “whatever action is necessary” to diminish the threat posed by Hezbollah. A senior official with the militant group warned that an overnight barrage of missiles against Israel was “just the beginning.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Sri Lanka Elects Leftist Leader Dissanayake as President
item.description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake’s strong showing reveals voter weariness with leadership that has led to a national economic crisis and crushing hardship for many people.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Pamodi Waravita
item.media:description: Anura Kumara Dissanayake, center, leaving a polling station after casting his vote in the presidential election in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Saturday.

item.title: U.N. Meets Amid a Backdrop of Growing Chaos and Violence
item.description: Beginning Tuesday, world leaders will discuss three wars, climate change, rising sea levels and proposals to expand representation on the Security Council.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The United Nations headquarters in New York. By most accounts, the world has descended even deeper into chaos and violence since last year’s meeting of the General Assembly.

item.title: At a Remote Scottish Pub, a Pint Worth Hiking 20 Miles
item.description: The Old Forge on the rugged peninsula of Knoydart is a community-owned meeting point for locals and visitors — at least those willing to trek across the wilderness.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The Old Forge is known as the remotest pub in mainland Britain.

item.title: Brandenburg State Elections: What to Watch For
item.description: The far right and far left are poised to make significant gains in state voting on Sunday, possibly affecting the stability of the national government in Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Dietmar Woidke, the governor of the eastern German state of Brandenburg, is one of the most popular members of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s party, but they have been facing headwinds.

item.title: Congo Releases More Than 700 Inmates After a Deadly Stampede
item.description: At least 129 people died when inmates tried to escape from Makala Prison, where conditions are abysmal and overcrowding is a major problem.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Inmates waiting to be released from Makala Prison in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on Saturday.

item.title: Explosion at an Iranian Mine Kills Dozens, State Media Says
item.description: A methane leak set off the explosion, the country’s official media said, and a rescue effort was underway for those believed to be trapped in the mine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: For Israel, Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Take a Back Seat to Military Force
item.description: After years of failed deals and tit-for-tat violence, neither the Israelis nor the Palestinians believe their adversaries will ever negotiate in good faith.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: The site of an Israeli airstrike in the southern Lebanese village of Khiam on Thursday. Recent attacks have fueled concerns of a broader regional war.

item.title: 1 Dead, Several Missing in Japan After Flooding and Landslides
item.description: One person is dead and seven others are missing in Noto Peninsula, Japanese news media reported. The region is still recovering from a catastrophic earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Residents survey damage after flooding due to heavy rains in Suzu, Ishikawa prefecture, on Saturday.

item.title: How a U.S. Ally Uses Aid as a Cover in War
item.description: The United Arab Emirates is expanding a covert campaign to back a winner in Sudan’s civil war. Waving the banner of the Red Crescent, it is also smuggling weapons and deploying drones.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Christoph Koettl
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies

item.title: Albania Plans to Create a Muslim State in Tirana as Symbol of Tolerance
item.description: Prime Minister Edi Rama says he wants to give members of the Bektashi, a Shiite Sufi order, their own Vatican-style enclave as a way of promoting religious tolerance.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The compound in Tirana, the Albanian capital, that would become the Sovereign State of the Bektashi Order.

item.title: Leader of Kenya, Donor to Haiti Police Force, Makes First Visit
item.description: The trip by President William Ruto of Kenya came against a bleak backdrop in Haiti, where gangs operate with impunity and the Kenyan officers remain largely out of sight.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President William Ruto of Kenya, center, with police officers from his country in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Saturday.

item.title: Macron Appoints Cabinet as He Seeks to Move France Out of Political Impasse
item.description: The government still faces two challenges in the coming weeks: the risk of a no-confidence vote and a tight budget deadline.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France hopes to move the country past a several-month-long political impasse.

item.title: In One Hezbollah-Dominated Neighborhood, a Mix of Defiance and Unease
item.description: Many residents of Dahiya were grappling with uncertainty over what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A funeral procession for two Hezbollah commanders moving through Beirut on Sunday.

item.title: Takeaways From ‘The Deserter’ in The New York Times Magazine
item.description: Here is what we can learn about the Russian military and its soldiers from the story of ‘Ivan’ and ‘Anna’ in The New York Times Magazine.
item.dc:creator: Sarah A. Topol
item.media:credit: Elinor Carucci for The New York Times

item.title: Videos From Kiryat Bialik Show Hezbollah Missile Striking Residential Area
item.description: An overnight barrage included around 150 rockets, cruise missiles and drones, Israel’s military said. Air defenses intercepted most, but the town of Kiryat Bialik suffered a direct hit.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese and Malachy Browne
item.media:description: A dashcam video captures the moment a missile fired by Hezbollah struck near Haifa in Israel.

item.title: Israel’s Military Closes Al Jazeera’s Office in the West Bank
item.description: The Israeli authorities have been putting pressure on the local operations of the network, saying its coverage threatens national security.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle outside the building that houses the Al Jazeera office in Ramallah, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, on Sunday.

item.title: For Americans Haunted by Beirut Bombings, a Killing Resurfaces Decades of Pain
item.description: The death of a Hezbollah leader wanted for his role in the 1983 attacks drew a range of reactions from survivors and victims’ families but brought little resolution.
item.dc:creator: Kate Selig
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The attack on the U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut, Lebanon, killed more than 300 people, mostly service members.

item.title: Israeli Attacks in Lebanon Mark a Sharp Strategic Shift
item.description: The events of this week seem to indicate that Israel’s leaders have decided they can no longer live with the threat of Hezbollah on their northern border, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Hwaida Saad, Ben Hubbard and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Saturday at the site of an Israeli airstrike in Beirut, Lebanon. Hezbollah has been left in deep disarray by attacks in the past week.

item.title: A Week of Chaos Pushes Lebanon’s Doctors to the Limit
item.description: Exploding wireless devices maimed thousands. An Israeli airstrike on Friday flattened two buildings. Many doctors, exhausted, wonder how the country will cope if violence continues.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: “I am hoping that it was all just a bad dream,” Dr. Dania El-Hallak said.

item.title: U.S. Soldier Pleads Guilty to Desertion After Fleeing Into North Korea
item.description: Pvt. Travis King on Friday pleaded guilty before a military judge to desertion, among other charges, after he made an unauthorized crossing into North Korea in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: U.S. Army Pvt. Travis King shown during a news broadcast in Seoul in 2023.

item.title: Israeli Strike on Former School Kills 22, Gazan Health Officials Say
item.description: Gaza’s ministry of health said most of those killed in the strike on the Zeitoun School in Gaza City were women and children.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Rawan Sheikh Ahmad
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Gaza’s rescue services said the Saturday strike on Gaza’s Zeitoun School killed mostly women and children.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Backs Down in Brazil
item.description: In an abrupt reversal, the social network’s lawyers said it was complying with court orders that it had previously defied. Brazil’s Supreme Court could allow the site to return next week.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazil’s Supreme Court blocked X last month because its owner, Elon Musk, refused to comply with court orders.

item.title: Who Was Ahmed Wahbi, One of the Hezbollah Commanders Killed by an Israeli Airstrike?
item.description: The senior Hezbollah leader trained the group’s elite fighting unit and led its support for Hamas after the Oct. 7 attacks, the Lebanese militia said.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Fighters wearing the insignia of the Hezbollah’s Radwan force during a training exercise in southern Lebanon in May 2023.

item.title: For Families of Those Missing After Israeli Strike in Beirut, an Agonizing Wait
item.description: With the death toll rising and rescuers still searching for people beneath the rubble, families were keeping a desperate watch over the site of an Israeli strike in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Saturday at a suburban Beirut residential building that was destroyed in an Israeli airstrike a day earlier.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Two More Russian Munition Depots
item.description: Strikes on weapons arsenals are crucial to weaken Moscow’s overwhelming superiority in battlefield firepower, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops during weapons training this month in the eastern Donetsk region.

item.title: Shoulder Season
item.description: It’s still summer today, but fall arrives tomorrow. Take a minute to pause on the threshold.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canadian Doctors Group Apologizes for Health Harms to Indigenous People
item.description: Indigenous patients faced abuse, experimental treatments and other harms in Canada’s health system, which still has disparities.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Hubert Hayaud for The New York Times
item.media:description: The former home of Joyce Echaquan, an Indigenous woman who was mocked and neglected by staff members in a Quebec hospital while she died.

item.title: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Alter Balance of Power in a Long-Running Fight
item.description: A focus on mutual deterrence had kept intermittent clashes along the Lebanon-Israel border from spiraling into a major war. That changed this past week.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters mourning the deaths of two people after a second wave of explosions followed this week’s pager attack.

item.title: Car Parts, Fiberglass and a Dream: How a Teacher Built a Hovercraft
item.description: Robert Tymofichuk, a teacher in Alberta, Canada, spent nearly 2,000 hours building an operational hovercraft from salvaged car parts and with no blueprint.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: It took Robert Tymofichuk, a teacher and assistant principal, a year to build a working hovercraft out of salvaged parts, including a 1997 Jeep Grand Cherokee.

item.title: How the Kremlin Might Get Past RT Bans to Spread Its Message
item.description: Social media companies may try to ban RT, the Russian state media broadcaster. But the network has proved in the past to be a wily adversary when confronted with efforts to silence it.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A control room for the Russian state media broadcaster RT, in Moscow, in 2018.

item.title: How Dangerous Is PFAS in Food?
item.description: There’s a growing understanding of the health threats of PFAS chemicals in what we eat and drink.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Greta Rybus for The New York Times
item.media:description: PFAS-contaminated beef from a farm in Maine.

item.title: Did PFAS From Sewage Sludge Poison a Family Farm?
item.description: Pastures were fertilized with toxic sewage decades ago. Nobody knew, until the cows’ milk was tested.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Greta Rybus for The New York Times

item.title: The Incumbent, the Marxist and the Heir: Sri Lanka’s Tight Race for President
item.description: The country will hold its first presidential election on Saturday since its strongman president fled the country two years ago. Here are the main contenders.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita

item.title: Senior Hezbollah Leader Is Killed in Beirut in Israeli Airstrike
item.description: The attack, which Lebanese officials said killed at least 14 and injured more than 60, stoked fears Israel is driving toward a full-blown war on its northern border, even as the fight in Gaza goes on.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: People gathering at a residential building in Beirut’s southern suburbs that was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike on Friday.

item.title: What Is The Radwan Force, the Elite Hezbollah Unit Linked to Ibrahim Aqeel?
item.description: The Israeli military considers the force a major threat to its northern border and has portrayed Aqeel, whom it claimed to have killed on Friday, as its de facto commander.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Fighters wearing the insignia of Hezbollah’s Radwan force during a training exercise in southern Lebanon in May 2023.

item.title: Remembering Toto Schillaci and a Summer That Changed Soccer
item.description: For one month in 1990, Schillaci was the most beloved player in Italy, and one of the most famous players in the world.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Salvatore Schillaci in 1990, the summer when he burst onto the stage at the World Cup. He died on Wednesday at age 59.

item.title: Israeli Soldiers Throw Three Seemingly Lifeless Palestinians Off a Roof
item.description: Several videos have emerged of the gruesome scene, but it remains unclear if the three were alive or dead at the time.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Aric Toler
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Netherlands Returns Hundreds of Cultural Artifacts to Indonesia
item.description: The repatriation, the second of its kind by the Dutch, shows a working model for returning looted treasures from Europe to former colonies around the world.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel

item.title: Israel’s Attacks on Hezbollah Have Intensified but Stop Short of All-Out War
item.description: Israel is attempting a risky strategy, increasing the intensity of its attacks in an attempt to force Hezbollah to back down, while raising the chances of an aggressive response that devolves into a land war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: People gathering at the scene of an Israeli strike in the southern suburbs of Beirut on Friday.

item.title: Who Is Ibrahim Aqeel, the Hezbollah Commander Targeted by Israel?
item.description: The senior leader, who had survived multiple assassination attempts, has been sought by the United States for bombings in the 1980s. Here is a closer look.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: The scene of an Israeli strike in the southern suburbs of Beirut on Friday.

item.title: Harrods Will Be Sued by Mohamed al-Fayed’s Alleged Victims, Lawyers Say
item.description: Attorneys for 37 women said they would sue Harrods, the luxury department store, over the rape and sexual assault they say its former owner committed.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Mohamed al-Fayed in 2008. A BBC documentary this week detailed allegations that Mr. al-Fayed, who died last year, had raped and sexually assaulted multiple female employees.

item.title: Nigel Farage’s Anti-Immigration Party Has Big Plans. Can It See Them Through?
item.description: Nigel Farage, a Trump ally and Brexit champion, thinks Reform U.K. can become a major political force. At a conference on Friday, he sought to explain how.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, leader of the Reform U.K. party, at its conference in Birmingham, England, on Friday.

item.title: After Pager Attack, Israel and Hezbollah Return to Familiar Deadlock
item.description: Israel’s attack on Hezbollah’s communication devices raised expectations of a decisive shift in their war of attrition. Instead, the fighting has returned to a standoff.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters mourning the deaths of two people during a second wave of explosions that struck Lebanon following the pager bomb attack.

item.title: China To ‘Gradually’ Resume Imports of Japanese Seafood
item.description: China imposed a ban last year after Japan began releasing treated water from the Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea. They have agreed to expand monitoring of the water.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Kiuko Notoya and Claire Fu
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sorting seafood at a port in the Fukushima prefecture of Japan last September, days after Japan started discharging treated water from the crippled nuclear plant nearby.

item.title: With Focus Shifting to Lebanon, Some in Gaza Fear Cease-Fire Talks Will Be Sidelined
item.description: Even as Israel signals that it is moving its focus to its northern border with Lebanon, there has been no pause to its bombardment in Gaza, where residents are facing another winter with little access to food or shelter.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Palestinians walk past rubble in Bureij in central Gaza on Tuesday.

item.title: Three Mile Island Plans to Reopen as Demand for Nuclear Power Grows
item.description: The infamous plant, closed since 2019, is getting a new lease on life after Microsoft agreed to buy its electricity to supply a growing fleet of data centers.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: The Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Londonderry Township, Pa.

item.title: A North Korean Trash Balloon Hits a Seoul Government Compound, Again
item.description: Debris was found more than a day after the North’s latest balloon launch. South Korea says it’s essentially impossible to track every balloon.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A view from Paju, South Korea, of balloons launched by North Korea earlier this month.

item.title: Biden Will Take Cancer ‘Moonshot’ Global at Summit in Delaware
item.description: The president will join the leaders of Australia, India and Japan to announce a new initiative for reducing cervical cancer in the Indo-Pacific, a region with especially high rates of the disease.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: President Biden in August. He began his cancer initiative in 2016, when he was vice president, after the death of his son Beau from an aggressive brain cancer.

item.title: Lebanese Talk of Revenge for Pager Attacks
item.description: After two days of exploding pagers and walkie-talkies, Beirut was a city on edge, with people worried there were bombs in their bags or pockets. Victims’ relatives vowed retribution.
item.dc:creator: Hwaida Saad and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters on Thursday surrounded the coffins of two people killed during explosions in Lebanon on Wednesday.

item.title: In Australia, an Old-Fashioned Art Is Having a Revival
item.description: Young practitioners are helping make stained glass, which fell out of fashion over two decades ago, a vibrant art form in Australia once again.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:credit: Dean Swindell for The New York Times
item.media:description: Australian-themed stained glass windows in Queensland, Australia, in 2018.

item.title: Europe’s New Defense Chief: ‘A King Without a Kingdom’?
item.description: The European Union has vowed to enhance its military capability. But money is scarce, responsibilities overlap and the new job is less about soldiers than arms manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Philipp von Ditfurth/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Andrius Kubilius, a former prime minister of Lithuania, has been named as the European Union commissioner for defense.

item.title: Israel Strikes Hezbollah as Nasrallah Vows Retribution
item.description: The Hezbollah leader, Hassan Nasrallah, did not say how his group would respond to attacks on hand-held devices, which killed dozens when pagers and walkie-talkies exploded.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hezbollah supporters in Beirut on Thursday mourned the deaths of two of their members in a second wave of explosions that struck Lebanon.

item.title: Walkie-Talkie and Pager Attacks Against Hezbollah Set Off Legal Debate
item.description: Experts are at odds over the question of whether it violates the laws of war to hide explosives in wireless devices that may go off near civilians.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives and friends mourning Fatima Abdullah, 9, who was killed by a pager explosion.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Bombards Hezbollah
item.description: Plus, French drag is here to stay.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Hezbollah supporter at a funeral for four people killed in the pager attacks.

item.title: U.N. Says Israeli War in Gaza Has ‘Catastrophic Consequences’ for Children
item.description: Israel has long blamed Hamas for civilian and children deaths, arguing that the militant group uses innocent people as human shields.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child
item.media:description: Palestinian children after a strike in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, in July.

item.title: Hezbollah Leader Says Israel Will Face Retribution After Lebanon Explosions
item.description: Hassan Nasrallah refused to say when or how Hezbollah would take revenge. As he spoke, Israeli fighter jets swooped low over Beirut.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s leader, in his first televised remarks in Lebanon on Thursday.
